User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686 (x86_64); en-GB; rv:1.9.1.18) Gecko/20110324 Iceweasel/3.5.18 (like Firefox/3.5.18)
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686 (x86_64); en-GB; rv:1.9.1.18) Gecko/20110324 Iceweasel/3.5.18 (like Firefox/3.5.18)

A URI may contain a fragment identifier; i.e., a literal '#' followed by some text identifying where, within the URI, is the point of interest.

For example, RFC 3778 describes how a URI to a file with MIME type 'application/pdf' may indicate page 5 is the target by appending '#page=5' to the end of the URI:

    http://www.example.org/path/to/file.pdf#page=5

When processing this file with a helper application, Firefox will download the file (file.pdf in above example) and run the application with 'file.pdf' as an argument and the additional location information from the URI fragment identifier (such as "page=5") has been lost.

The result is that the end-user experience is diminished: she selects a link that describes exactly where to look within the PDF document, only ending up having to search around for the correct place within that file.

The problem is present for all URI types and (I suspect) some form of generic support for URI fragment handling will be needed.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Configure Firefox to use a help application to serve PDF content.
2. Navigate to a web-page with a link to some PDF where the URI contains a fragment identifier (e.g., '#page=5')
3. Select the link
Actual Results:  
PDF file opens, but not at the correct location (e.g., page 5)

Expected Results:  
PDF file opens at the correct location (e.g., page 5).

I've only tested this with Linux machine and okular; but, from what I've seen, it seems an architecture problem rather than one of configuration.
